issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: euca_ipt is not currently ignoring duplicate addition rules

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
After running then terminating instances in serial for over 12hrs I saw an issue where instances were no longer reachable. The cause was that the same IP was being reused and the IP that was being used had a stale entry in the CC meaning two private IPs were assigned to the same public IP in iptables.

I see this in the log but dont believe that it actually happened:
{code}
2012-10-31 11:00:40  WARN | Forgetting stale orphan address mapping for ClusterAddressInfo 10.111.54.100 172.22.128.151
{code}

debug info:

fields.summary: After long running test, orphaned public/private IP address mapping causing instances to be unreachable

comments.body:
I am seeing the POSTROUTING rules in the nat table accumulate even after 100 instances launched:
{code}
[root@b-34 ~]# iptables -L -t nat
Chain PREROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
DNAT       tcp  --  anywhere             169.254.169.254     tcp dpt:http to:10.111.1.34:8773 

Chain POSTROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
SNAT       all  --  172.22.186.238       anywhere            to:10.111.54.100 
SNAT       all  --  172.22.160.50        anywhere            to:10.111.54.100 
SNAT       all  --  172.22.144.39        anywhere            to:10.111.54.100 
MASQUERADE  all  --  172.22.128.0/18     !172.22.128.0/18     

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
[root@b-34 ~]# 
{code}
Was able to reproduce 2 more times by running concurrent instances at staggered intervals. 1 failure happened with 20mins while running 8 threads.

I was able to reproduce this in a few minutes using the following:

{code}
while true; do euca-describe-instances | grep terminated | awk '{print $2}' | xargs euca-terminate-instances &>/dev/null; sleep 3; done &
while true; do euca-describe-instances | grep running | awk '{print $2}' | head -n 1 | xargs euca-terminate-instances &>/dev/null; sleep 3; done &
while true; do euca-run-instances emi-???????? &>/dev/null; sleep 0.1; done &
while true; do euca-run-instances emi-???????? &>/dev/null; sleep 0.1; done &
{code}

the "emi-????????" above needs to be replaced with an available machine image.

When the issue occurred the following IP tables rules were set:

{code}
# iptables -L -n -t nat
Chain PREROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
DNAT       tcp  --  0.0.0.0/0            169.254.169.254     tcp dpt:80 to:192.168.51.169:8773 
DNAT       tcp  --  0.0.0.0/0            169.254.169.254     tcp dpt:80 to:192.168.51.169:8773 
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            192.168.40.72       to:10.211.46.187 
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            192.168.40.73       to:10.211.46.177 
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            192.168.40.75       to:10.211.46.176 

Chain POSTROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
SNAT       all  --  10.211.46.176        0.0.0.0/0           to:192.168.40.75 
SNAT       all  --  10.211.46.177        0.0.0.0/0           to:192.168.40.73 
SNAT       all  --  10.211.46.187        0.0.0.0/0           to:192.168.40.72 
SNAT       all  --  10.211.46.171        0.0.0.0/0           to:192.168.40.75 
MASQUERADE  all  --  10.211.32.0/20      !10.211.32.0/20      

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            192.168.40.72       to:10.211.46.187 
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            192.168.40.73       to:10.211.46.177 
DNAT       all  --  0.0.0.0/0            192.168.40.75       to:10.211.46.176 
{code}

The information returned from the cluster controller to the cloud controller for instances is:

{code}
VmInfo r-B2054497 i-109640BC KIXEGM6GDOHRMLC9CRMAX Teardown VmTypeInfo m1.small mem=512 disk=5 cores=1    0 http://192.168.51.173:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC NetworkConfig 119 28 10.211.46.188 0.0.0.0 null null []
VmInfo r-C306413E i-54983FF3 KIXEGM6GDOHRMLC9CRMAX Teardown VmTypeInfo m1.small mem=512 disk=5 cores=1    0 http://192.168.51.173:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC NetworkConfig 119 14 10.211.46.174 0.0.0.0 null null []
VmInfo r-4FEC3FF9 i-D82C44F3 KIXEGM6GDOHRMLC9CRMAX Teardown VmTypeInfo m1.small mem=512 disk=5 cores=1    0 http://192.168.51.173:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC NetworkConfig 119 29 10.211.46.189 0.0.0.0 null null []
VmInfo r-FC02448E i-0F5A3D44 KIXEGM6GDOHRMLC9CRMAX Teardown VmTypeInfo m1.small mem=512 disk=5 cores=1    0 http://192.168.51.173:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC NetworkConfig 119 13 10.211.46.173 0.0.0.0 null null []
